children.title: blood
children.comment: The symbol of life, which thus plays an especially important role in the sacrificial system of the OT. The shedding of the blood of a sacrificial animal represents the giving up of its life. The ``blood of Christ'' refers to Jesus Christ's obedient giving of his life, in order to achieve redemption and forgiveness.

children.title: ceremonies

children.title: circumcision
children.comment: The practice of cutting away the foreskin of male children, usually within a short time of birth. In the OT, the practice is seen as a sign of membership of the people of God. The NT makes it clear that Christians are under no obligation to be circumcised.

children.title: circumcision, spiritual
children.comment: On its own, the physical sign of circumcision is no guarantee of finding favour in the sight of God. It was intended to be the outward sign of inward consecration and should be accompanied by repentance, faith and obedience. Paul stresses that circumcision confers no special privileges upon individuals; it is faith in God, rather than any outward sign, that ensures that believers stand in a right relationship to God.

The motives and intentions of the heart were also sometimes judged to be clean or unclean, as uncleanness was often linked with sin.

children.title: feasts and festivals
children.comment: The OT makes reference to a number of feasts and festivals, which generally commemorate an event in Israel's history (e.g., the Feast of Passover) or some season of the year (e.g., the Feast of Weeks). In the NT, some of these festivals are given new meanings, such as Pentecost, which was originally a harvest festival, but which came to celebrate the coming of the Holy Spirit.

children.title: feasts and festivals, nature of
children.comment: Israel's feasts and festivals were to be times of religious and community celebration. Ordained by God, they were to be the outward expression of a right spirital attitude.

Feast of Dedication
children.comment: This feast began on 25th Kislev (November/December) and lasted seven days. It celebrated the cleansing of the temple and altar by Judas Maccabeus after they had been defiled by Antiochus Epiphanes.

children.title: Jesus Christ was challenged to declare his messiahship at the Feast of Dedication

children.comment: The date of the offering of firstfruits, a celebration of God's gift of the harvest, is not clear; it was probably held on 16th Abib.

Feast of Tabernacles
children.comment: This feast began on 15th Tishri (September/October) and lasted seven days. It celebrated the first gathering of the fruit and grain harvests and also God's provision for his people during their wilderness journey from Egypt to the promised land.

children.title: Feast of Trumpets
children.comment: This feast, which is not specifically mentioned as such in the OT, took place at the observance of the new moon in the month of Tishri (September/October). It signalled the end of the agricultural year.

children.title: It was to be a day of rest, commemorated with the sounding of trumpets

children.comment: The feast was kept from 15th-21st Abib (March/April), to commemorate the haste with which the Israelites left Egypt. It was always celebrated in the calendar of feasts with the Feast of Passover.

high priest

children.title: high priest, in NT
children.comment: Under the Roman administration the high priest remained the senior Jewish leader, but his power was limited by Roman supervision.

children.title: High priests of the NT

secondaryrefs.comment: Annas was high priest from A.D. 6 until deposed by the Roman official, Gratus, in A.D. 15. Though replaced by his son Eleazar and, in A.D. 18, by Caiaphas, his son-in-law, Annas retained his authority in Jewish eyes. Strictly, there could only be one high priest at a time. Ananias, the high priest of Ac 23:2, was not related to the family of Annas.

cschildren.title: Terms used to describe the Most Holy Place

secondaryrefs.comment: ``the Most Holy Place'' (or ``Holy of Holies''), in contrast to the ``Holy Place'' where the altar stood. This superlative suggests increasing closeness to the presence of God. The distinction is not always observed, however. In Leviticus chapter 16 ``Holy Place'' is used regularly (translated in NIV as ``Most Holy Place'' in verses 2, 16, 17, 20, 27, and as ``sanctuary area'' in verse 3, though it is the inner sanctuary that is referred to, as the phrase ``behind the curtain'' (verse 2) shows)

children.title: New Year, the
children.comment: With the exception of one reference (Ex 12:2) the New Year is never specifically dated. The religious calendar apparently began in the spring and the agricultural calendar in the autumn. Later Judaism began its calendar in the autumn.

cschildren.title: Evidence that the autumn was regarded as the New Year

children.title: The dedication of Solomon's temple

primaryrefs.comment: Solomon waited 11 months after the completion of the temple (see 1Ki 6:38), before dedicating it, most likely because the great Feast of Tabernacles marked the beginning of the year.

children.title: Instructions for celebrating the Year of Jubilee

primaryrefs.comment: The Year of Jubilee was to be proclaimed on the tenth day of the seventh month, which was also the Day of Atonement.

children.title: Ezekiel's vision of the new temple

primaryrefs.comment: This vision of the new temple takes place at the beginning of the year. The ``tenth of the month'' refers presumably to the seventh month.

phylactery
children.comment: A leather box containing four sections of the law (Ex 11:13-21) written on parchment, and which Jewish men tied to the forehead and left arm (close to the heart) before morning prayers. The practice of wearing phylacteries arose, probably after the exile, from a literal interpretation by pious Jews of passages such as Ex 13:9.

children.title: priesthood
children.comment: The body of people responsible for priestly duties, especially in relation to worship and sacrifice. The OT identifies Aaron and his heirs as having special priestly duties. In the NT, all believers are understood to share in this priesthood. Jesus Christ fulfils the OT concept of priesthood by being both the high priest and sacrifice, through which forgiveness of sins is completely achieved.

children.comment: The day of rest laid down for the people of God. The OT treated the seventh day of the week (Saturday) as the Sabbath, a custom continued in modern Judaism. children.title: shrine
children.comment: A local sanctuary, often dedicated to pagan worship. Before the building of the temple the Israelites worshipped at several divinely sanctioned shrines; afterwards, worship at a central sanctuary was required. True worship of God required that pagan shrines be destroyed. It was Israel's failure to abandon these religious sites that led to syncretism and apostasy.

slavery
children.comment: The state of being an unpaid servant, whether through forcible subjection or voluntary submission. Slavery was common in biblical times, and Scripture lays down strict guidelines as to how slaves are to be treated by their masters, stressing the new status that slaves have as a result of being believers in Jesus Christ. The image of slavery is also used to describe the state of sinful human beings.

children.title: slavery, in OT
children.comment: Slavery in the OT occurs when someone either voluntarily or forcibly becomes completely subject to another person's control.

children.title: teachers of the law
children.comment: Those professionally trained to develop, teach and apply the OT law. In the application of the law the oral teaching of these people often assumed greater authority than the written law. Thus, by the time of the NT, the teachers of the law were in conflict with Jesus Christ and the apostles, who taught with authority and condemned the outward religious acts that the teachers had fostered.

children.title: temples
children.comment: Buildings for the worship of local or national gods. After settling in the promised land, Israel felt the need for a permanent building set apart for worship of the LORD. Three temples were built at different periods in Jerusalem. In the NT the individual believer (or the body of the church) is seen as the true temple or dwelling-place of God.

children.title: temple, Solomon's
children.comment: From the exodus until the reign of Solomon, the tabernacle located in various places served as Israel's ``temple'' and the ordained place of sacrifice. Solomon built the first temple in Jerusalem.

children.title: Tent of Meeting
children.comment: A tent pitched by Moses outside the Israelite camp in the wilderness. There Moses met with God and others would enquire of the LORD. God's presence was shown there by a pillar of cloud. It seems to predate the construction and setting up of the tabernacle, after which, the term became synonymous with the tabernacle.

cschildren.title: Moses pitched the Tent of Meeting outside the Israelite camp

primaryrefs.comment: The tent was outside the camp because of the LORD's estrangement from his people (Ex 33:3) following their making the golden calf. It was possibly a temporary structure used until the tabernacle was completed.

cschildren.title: The Tent of Meeting was where the faithful met with God

children.title: Year of Jubilee
children.comment: Celebrated in the fiftieth year as the culmination of seven sabbatical years. During this year property was restored and Hebrew slaves were released. This year of liberation gave opportunity for a new start, and is alluded to as a type of the Messianic age.

children.title: A means of preserving the inheritance from God

primaryrefs.comment: Families are urged to buy back land assigned to them by God. As a last resort, land is restored in the Year of Jubilee.
